article:
'Debagging' (the formal name used in Britain, especially historically at the
University of Oxford and Cambridge in England, and derived from "Oxford bags", a
loose-fitting baggy form of trousers), also known as 'kegging', 'dacking',
'downtrouting'/'downtrailing', 'jocking', 'trunking' or 'pantsing'/'de-pantsing'
(the North American term for the
act), [http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/20002684 Oxford English
Dictionary] is the pulling down of a person's trousers against their
wishes, typically as a practical joke, but in other instances as a sexual
fetish. The most common method is to sneak up behind the intended victim, grab
the trousers' waistband, and apply a quick downward tug before the victim is
aware of the debagger's presence. Sometimes, the trousers are completely
removed, and perhaps left somewhere embarrassing to reclaim.

The corresponding term in Australia is 'dakking' or 'dacking', which originated
from DAKS Simpson, a clothing brand that became a generic term for trousers and
underpants. [http://www.oup.com.au/dictionaries/wotm/dak Oxford University
Press, "Dak", Word of the Month, 2010.] (Retrieved 22 October
2010). McClure, Geoff. [http://www.theage.com.au/news/sport/campo-point-of-view-gets-a-
makeover/2006/02/15/1139890806854.html "Campo 'point' of view gets a makeover"]
The Age 16 February 2006. Retrieved 25 August 2009. In Scotland the
process is often known as 'breeking' from the word "breeks" meaning trousers. In
New Zealand the act is known as giving someone 'a down trou'; in Ireland
'jocking'; in the north of England 'kegging'. The act of pulling down a person's
underwear, is called double-dacking.

Debagging is a common prank in high school gym classes as a form of bullying. [http://books.google.com/books?id=oAFlDy4-
3pkC&pg=PA84&dq=depantsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is-
=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=depantsing&f=false] Roberts, Walter
B."Bullying From Both Sides: Strategic Interventions for Working With Bullies &
Victims" Corwin Press, 2005. Pages 84-85. ISBN 1-4129-2580-0 ISBN 978-1-4129-2580-
8 [http://books.google.com/books?id=JUyqzGlx0gAC&pg=PA6&dq=depantsing-
&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=-
onepage&q=depantsing&f=false] Voors, William, "The parent's book about bullying:
changing the course of your child's life." Hazelden, 2000. Page 6. ISBN 1-56838-517-
X ISBN 978-1-56838-517-4. Retrieved 25 August 2009 Its most extreme form
includes running the trousers up the school flagpole. [http://books.google.-
com/books?id=uoXKtfx4weoC&pg=PA120&dq=depantsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&-
as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=depantsing&f=false]
Cunningham, Patricia and Lab, Susan, "Dress and popular culture." Popular Press,
1991.Page 120. ISBN 0-87972-507-9 ISBN 978-0-87972-507-5 Retrieved 25 August
2009. Some U.S. colleges before World War II were the scenes of large
scale "depantsing" scraps between freshman and sophomore males. [http://dig-
italnewspapers.libraries.psu.edu/Default/Skins/BasicArch/Client.asp?Skin=BasicA-
rch&&AppName=2&enter=true&BaseHref=DCG/1950/09/13&EntityId=Ar00100 "Customs were
rugged then."] The Daily Collegian (Penn State), 13 September 1950. Volume 51,
no. 2, page 1. Retrieved 25 August 2009. It is also an initiation rite in
fraternities [http://books.google.com/books?id=4htx62wIXIgC&pg=PT177&dq=dep-
antsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_b-
rr=0#v=onepage&q=depantsing&f=false] Hodapp,Christopher and Von Kannon, Alice
"Conspiracy Theories & Secret Societies For Dummies."For Dummies, 2008. Page
159. ISBN 0-470-18408-6 ISBN 978-0-470-18408-0 Retrieved 25 August 2009
and seminaries. [http://books.google.com/books?id=MUYn5ydZ_HwC&pg=PA164&dq=-
depantsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&a-
s_brr=0#v=onepage&q=depantsing&f=false] Jordan, Mark D. "The Silence of Sodom:
Homosexuality in Modern Catholicism." University Of Chicago Press, 2002. Page
164. ISBN 0-226-41043-9 ISBN 978-0-226-41043-2Retrieved 25 August 2009 It
was cited in 1971 by Gail Sheehy as a form of sexual assault against grade
school girls, which did not commonly get reported, although it might include
improper touching and indecent exposure by the perpetrators. [http://books.google.com/books?id=B-
MCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA28&dq=depantsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_m-
axm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=pantsing&f=false] Sheehy, Gail, "Nice
girls don't get into trouble." New York Magazine 15 Feb 1971, page 28. Retrieved
25 August 2009, The United States legal system has prosecuted it as a form
of sexual harassment of children. [http://books.google.com/books?id=-ym-Zjn9-
zQC&pg=PA137&dq=depantsing&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is-
=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=depantsing&f=false] Martinson, Floyd
Mansfield, "The sexual life of children." Bergin & Garvey, 1994, Page 136. ISBN
0-89789-376-X ISBN 978-0-89789-376-3. Retrieved 25 August 2009
categories: Terminology of the University of Cambridge
Terminology of the University of Oxford
